documentType: Bureau of Prisons clinical and administrative records
summary: This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and a disciplinary process report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 27-30, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). The notes detail his mental status, complaints about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his inability to recall how he received neck injuries, and his eventual evaluation as competent to face disciplinary charges for attempted self-mutilation. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 31 to August 8, 2019. It includes a clinical contact note, a detailed suicide risk assessment, and a follow-up session. The reports document Epstein's mental status, his denial of suicidal ideation, and the investigation into an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck. The overall assessment concludes his acute suicide risk is low.

events.title: Epstein Incident in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged with a code 228 violation (attempted suicide or self-mutilation) after an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) that resulted in marks on his neck. He claims not to remember how the injuries occurred.

events.title: Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on daily psychological observation following the SHU incident. Notes document his mental status, complaints about SHU conditions, sleep deprivation, and interactions with staff and legal counsel.

events.title: Competency Evaluation for Disciplinary Process
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by psychology staff and found COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding the July 23rd incident report for attempted self-mutilation.

events.title: Cell Transfer Due to Malfunctioning Toilet
events.description: Epstein reported a toilet that flushed continuously for 45 minutes, which he found highly aversive and upsetting, comparing it to noise in SHU. The Lt. arranged for him to be moved to a different cell.

events.title: Incident with String Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found by staff in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember anything about it. The report notes it is unclear if he placed it there or someone else did.

events.title: Clinical Follow-up After Removal from Observation
events.description: Epstein is seen for a follow-up appointment after being removed from Psychological Observation. He reports doing well, denies suicidal ideation, and is adjusting to being back in SHU.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment Triggered by Marshals Form
events.description: R&D staff report that US Marshals asked Epstein to sign a form noting he has 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court. This triggers a formal Suicide Risk Assessment, which concludes his acute risk is low.

events.title: Weekly Psychology Follow-up in SHU
events.description: Epstein is seen for a follow-up session in SHU. He reports feeling okay, denies mental health symptoms and suicidal ideation, and states he spends his days with his attorneys.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY) - Facility NYM
SHU (Special Housing Unit / Administrative Segregation at NYM)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein, while in custody at MCC-NY, sustained unexplained neck injuries in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on or before July 23, 2019, which he repeatedly stated he could not remember how they occurred.
Epstein was evaluated as COMPETENT to face disciplinary charges for 'attempted suicide or self-mutilation' (Code 228) related to the neck injury incident.
Clinical notes detail Epstein's significant anxiety about returning to the SHU, complaints of severe sleep deprivation due to noise, and physical complaints including arm and neck numbness.
Epstein suggested he 'may have something on the Autism spectrum,' comparing himself to a character in 'Rain Man' and noting an aversion to noise and being 'really good with numbers.'
The documents show Epstein was frequently out of his cell for approximately 12 hours per day for legal visits with his attorneys, during which he also took meals.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; the report states 'it is unclear at this time if Mr. Epstein had placed the string around his own neck or if someone else did.'
A Suicide Risk Assessment on August 1, 2019, was triggered because US Marshals asked Epstein to sign a form noting he had 'suicidal tendencies' after returning from court.
Epstein consistently denied recent and current suicidal ideation, planning, and intent during all evaluations in late July and early August 2019.

The psychological assessment identified static risk factors for suicide including 'High Profile Crime', 'Lack of family connections', and 'Sex offender status', but concluded protective factors overrode them, resulting in a 'Low' overall acute suicide risk.
Epstein reported that his 'friends and Lawyers are emotionally supportive' and that he planned to 'finish this case and to go back to his normal life.'
